item.title: Mac setup (Part 0)
item.description:
VPNs, SSH reverse tunnels, Syngergy -> Barrier -> Input Leap, KVMs. I’ve dodged using the Mac for nearly eight years, but now I have to give in.

WARNING: This post might seem obvious to many macOS users.

Coming from the Linux world of personal computers and having used tiling windows managers for a while now, I always struggle with using Mac OS at work. I don’t like it a single bit. I hate inability of solving problems, the lack of customization and control you have over the OS. But if there’s one thing that I hate the most is the fact that, as an user, one must forfeit to Apple’s concept of what a good UX is and not the other way around. Having the chance to bring the UX closer to the individual, while maintaining a usable software for the herd, is something they just don’t care and I don’t blame them. Nevertheless, there are some things I have done to try to make my experience better.

item.title: Dealing with your private key
item.description:
Now that you’ve managed to create your own GPG key it’s time to understand a bit more about how GnuPG works.

The first question we need to ask is where are our keys stored. The answer depends on which version of GnuPG you are running. From version 2.1 onwards the method of storing your keys has change. On previous versions our keys were stored in two separate keyring under the ~/.gnupg directory. Prior version to 2.1 used to keep the public key pairs in two files: pubring.gpg and secring.gpg, you can imagine which stores which.
